cmCourseInfo.description: This course in Modern Irish Language is designed for learners with no prior knowledge of the language. The course is intended to introduce students to and provide practice in the four language skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the Irish Language

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course in Modern Irish Language is designed for learners with no prior knowledge of the language. The course is intended to introduce students to and provide practice in the four language skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

courses.name: The Celts in the Ancient and Medieval World

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the culture and literature of the Celtic peoples in pre-history and in the Middle Ages.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Celts in the Ancient and Medieval World

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

An introduction to the culture and literature of the Celtic peoples in pre-history and in the Middle Ages.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to Lowland Scots language and literature. Students will acquire fundamentals of reading, writing, grammar and spoken Scots. Poetry, songs and folktales introduce students to the language, literature and folklore of the Scots language, from the Renaissance poets through to Burns, MacDiarmid and modern artists. No prior knowledge of the language is required.
cmCourseInfo.title: Lowland Scots Language and Literature

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

An introduction to Lowland Scots language and literature. Students will acquire fundamentals of reading, writing, grammar and spoken Scots. Poetry, songs and folktales introduce students to the language, literature and folklore of the Scots language, from the Renaissance poets through to Burns, MacDiarmid and modern artists. No prior knowledge of the language is required.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers the range of the Celtic mythological record from all the Celtic areas through an examination of the archaeological, inscriptional and textual sources. A critical evaluation is offered of various relevant mythic approaches.
cmCourseInfo.title: Celtic Mythology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course covers the range of the Celtic mythological record from all the Celtic areas through an examination of the archaeological, inscriptional and textual sources. A critical evaluation is offered of various relevant mythic approaches.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course builds on CLT141Y1 Introduction to the Irish Language. It will provide further expansion of the four language skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Irish Language I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course builds on CLT141Y1 Introduction to the Irish Language. It will provide further expansion of the four language skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is a continuation of CLT251H1 Intermediate Irish Language I. It will provide further expansion of language skills. We will examine literary texts, both prose and poetry.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Irish Language II

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course is a continuation of CLT251H1 Intermediate Irish Language I. It will provide further expansion of language skills. We will examine literary texts, both prose and poetry.

cmCourseInfo.description: Sport in Ireland is a course designed to investigate the role sport has had since the inception of the Irish Free State in 1922 up until the present day. The course aims to explore the position of sport at a regional level in Ireland as well as the differences existing between certain sporting organizations at a regional and national level. The course will also determine sport’s contribution to the identity of Ireland in its first one hundred years as a nation state.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sport in Ireland
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: CLT333H1 (Special Topics in Celtic Studies I: Sport in Ireland), offered in Fall 2022

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Sport in Ireland is a course designed to investigate the role sport has had since the inception of the Irish Free State in 1922 up until the present day. The course aims to explore the position of sport at a regional level in Ireland as well as the differences existing between certain sporting organizations at a regional and national level. The course will also determine sport’s contribution to the identity of Ireland in its first one hundred years as a nation state.

cmCourseInfo.description: The history of the insular Celtic nation groups from the post-Roman period to the end of the first millennium, the course will trace settlement history and social organization, the making of Celtic nations, the process of Christianization, the impact of the Vikings, and the rise of paramount kings.
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Celtic History 450-1000

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

The history of the insular Celtic nation groups from the post-Roman period to the end of the first millennium, the course will trace settlement history and social organization, the making of Celtic nations, the process of Christianization, the impact of the Vikings, and the rise of paramount kings.

cmCourseInfo.description: Over 70 million people in the world can claim Irish descent. Since the 17th century, Irish people have voluntarily migrated and have been forcibly transported to a variety of global destinations. This course explores the "push and pull" factors that prompted these migrations and focuses on the diasporic communities created by Irish Catholics and Protestants in Great Britain, Canada, the United States, Continental Europe, the Caribbean, Argentina, South Africa, India, Australia, and New Zealand.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Irish Diaspora

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Over 70 million people in the world can claim Irish descent. Since the 17th century, Irish people have voluntarily migrated and have been forcibly transported to a variety of global destinations. This course explores the "push and pull" factors that prompted these migrations and focuses on the diasporic communities created by Irish Catholics and Protestants in Great Britain, Canada, the United States, Continental Europe, the Caribbean, Argentina, South Africa, India, Australia, and New Zealand.

courses.name: Traditional Music in Ireland and Scotland

cmCourseInfo.description: From Medieval harp playing to the emergence of reels and jigs during the eighteenth century, this course explores the changes and continuities in traditional music, and its place in contemporary culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Traditional Music in Ireland and Scotland

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

From Medieval harp playing to the emergence of reels and jigs during the eighteenth century, this course explores the changes and continuities in traditional music, and its place in contemporary culture.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on Irish history from the early seventeenth century to the Great Famine of the mid nineteenth century. Topics include the Ulster plantation, Catholic resistance, the Penal Laws, the United Irishmen, the Act of Union, Catholic Emancipation and the Famine.
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Modern Ireland

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course focuses on Irish history from the early seventeenth century to the Great Famine of the mid nineteenth century. Topics include the Ulster plantation, Catholic resistance, the Penal Laws, the United Irishmen, the Act of Union, Catholic Emancipation and the Famine.

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of the production of manuscripts, books and tracts that played a crucial role in the historical evolution of a national culture or cultures in the Celtic world.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Celtic Book

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

A study of the production of manuscripts, books and tracts that played a crucial role in the historical evolution of a national culture or cultures in the Celtic world.

cmCourseInfo.description: A research project chosen by the student in consultation with a faculty supervisor and approved by the Program Coordinator. A full proposal including a course description, working bibliography, marking scheme, and approval from your academic supervisor must be submitted for approval by the Program Coordinator and Director. More information and application forms are available at https://stmikes.utoronto.ca/smc-ind-study-form or from the SMC Principal's Office, smc.programs@utoronto.ca. Completed forms must be submitted to the Principal's Office by the first day of classes in September/May for F courses, or January/July for S courses. Meeting times are determined in consultation with your supervisor, and may be in person or online as appropriate. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the extent to which the Irish can be understood as a colonized and racialized people, and the degree to which they participated in the colonization and racialization of Blacks and Indigenous peoples in the British and American empires. It encompasses debates about whether the Irish were victims of genocidal policies during the Famine, and their role in what one historian calls the “casual genocide” of imperial expansion. It also discusses the character and limitations of anti-colonialism in Irish nationalist discourse, and attitudes of racialized minorities and Indigenous peoples towards the Irish. This course is jointly offered with the graduate course, HIS1441H.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ireland, Race and Empires

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course examines the extent to which the Irish can be understood as a colonized and racialized people, and the degree to which they participated in the colonization and racialization of Blacks and Indigenous peoples in the British and American empires. It encompasses debates about whether the Irish were victims of genocidal policies during the Famine, and their role in what one historian calls the “casual genocide” of imperial expansion. It also discusses the character and limitations of anti-colonialism in Irish nationalist discourse, and attitudes of racialized minorities and Indigenous peoples towards the Irish. This course is jointly offered with the graduate course, HIS1441H.

cmCourseInfo.description: Middle Welsh, the native Celtic language of medieval Wales, was for centuries the language in which the Welsh celebrated their medieval princes and ancestral heroes, was the medium for the preservation of native British legend and Welsh law, and was the vehicle for the earliest narratives of Arthur. Students will be introduced to reading and translating Middle Welsh, and by the course’s end will have read one complete text of Middle Welsh literature in the original. Students will learn Welsh specifically but will also learn the characteristic linguistic features of a Celtic language. No prior knowledge of Welsh or any other Celtic language is assumed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Middle Welsh
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of 9.0 credits or permission of the instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Middle Welsh, the native Celtic language of medieval Wales, was for centuries the language in which the Welsh celebrated their medieval princes and ancestral heroes, was the medium for the preservation of native British legend and Welsh law, and was the vehicle for the earliest narratives of Arthur. Students will be introduced to reading and translating Middle Welsh, and by the course’s end will have read one complete text of Middle Welsh literature in the original. Students will learn Welsh specifically but will also learn the characteristic linguistic features of a Celtic language. No prior knowledge of Welsh or any other Celtic language is assumed.
